text: Green Lantern is the name of several fictional superheroes that appear in comic books published by DC Comics. The first was Alan Scott and was created by writer Bill Finger and artist Martin Nodell in All-American Comics #16 in July 1940. The most famous is Hal Jordan and was created by John Broome and Gil Kane in Showcase #22 in October 1959. Each Green Lantern wears a power ring that allows the Green Lantern to control the physical world by strength of will. Alan Scott was the Golden Age Green Lantern and his ring was powered by magic. All of the Green Lanterns since then have worn rings that were not magic, but advanced technology. The Guardians of the Universe created the power rings and granted them to worthy candidates throughout the galaxy. These individuals make up the Green Lantern Corps, an intergalactic police force. there are other lantern corps which represent different emotions and like Willpower the rings are only given to people who display a lot of a certain emotion, good or bad but not all. Blue Lantern corps "Hope" Red Lantern corps "Anger" Orange Lantern corps "Greed" Yellow Lantern corps "Fear" Black Lantern corps "Death" White Lantern corps "Rebirth" Indigo Lantern corps "Compassion" Green Lantern corps "Willpower" Hal Jordan's archenemy is Sinestro of the Yellow Lantern Corps. == Fictional character biographies == === Golden Age Green Lantern: Alan Scott === Alan Scott was a young engineer when he found a metal lantern that glowed with a magical green flame. The flame told Alan how to build a ring. Alan used the power of the ring to fight crime. Alan was a founding member of the Justice Society of America. Alan Scott's power ring had to be recharged every 24 hours and did not work on wood. === Silver Age Green Lantern: Hal Jordan === Hal Jordan was an airplane test pilot. Jordan was given his power ring by a dying alien named Abin Sur, whose spaceship had crashed on Earth. Jordan was a founding member of the Justice League of America and also a member of the Green Lantern Corps. At first, Hal Jordan's power ring didn't work on anything yellow. Hal Jordan's hometown Coast City was destroyed in the early 1990s and he went insane. Jordan destroyed the Green Lantern Corps and renamed himself Parallax. Jordan later died, sacrificing himself to reignite a dying Sun only to return from the grave as the Spectre, the divine Spirit of God's Vengeance. Hal Jordan was later brought back to life and he once again became a Green Lantern. He also made an oath to recharge the power ring: "In brightest day, in blackest night No evil shall escape my sight, Let those who worship evil's might, Beware my power...Green lantern's light!" === Bronze Age Green Lanterns === Guy Gardner Guy Gardner was the second choice of Abin Sur and the backup to Hal Jordan. John Stewart John Stewart, an architect, was chosen by the Guardians to replace Guy Gardner as the backup Green Lantern for Hal Jordan. === Modern Age Green Lantern: Kyle Rayner === Kyle Rayner Kyle Rayner, a freelance artist, was given the last power ring, and restored the Guardians and Corps after Jordan destroyed them as Parallax. Later Kyle became Ion, the manifestation of willpower, for a short time. == In other media == The character has been adapted to different forms of media, such as toys, movies, television series, and video games as well. The Hal Jordan version of the character is portrayed by Ryan Reynolds in the 2011 movie Green Lantern. Category:DC Comics superheroes Category:DC Comics adapted into movies
